G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 231, § 1, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and this is an action sounding in tort.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 and G.L. c. 231, § 1, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and this is an action sounding in tort.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20133.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant is organized under the laws of Massachusetts and/or regularly conducts business in Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred within Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Bristol County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the events giving rise to this lawsuit occurred at Defendant’s facility at 123 Main Street, Brockton, Massachusetts, which is within Bristol County, and Defendant conducts business in this county.

*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a person or entity that undertakes the supervision and care of a minor child owes that child a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect the child from foreseeable harm.
*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects imposing a duty on a parent who merely allows or supervises a teen party where minors drink, when the parent did not provide or make available the alcohol. The court holds that, even if the parent knew or should have known minors would drink and might pose a risk of harm to others, Massachusetts common law does not recognize a duty of reasonable care in these circumstances. Thus, the case is authority against, not for, the claimed proposition.
*Wallace v. Wilson*, 411 Mass. 8, 12 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available. The defendant’s conduct did not create a risk of injury to the plaintiff for which we are prepared to say the common law should provide a remedy. … We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here.”

*Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 745,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a person or entity that undertakes the supervision and care of a minor child owes that child a duty to exercise reasonable care to protect the child from foreseeable harm.
*Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 745,.support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses “special relationships” that create duties to protect others from third‑party harm and cites, as an example, that a group child care facility has a duty to control acts of delinquent children. It relies on general tort principles that one who undertakes supervision and care of another (including minors) must exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm from third persons, and it collects authority including Eldredge v. Kamp Kachess Youth Serv., a child‑care case, to illustrate that duty. This aligns with the proposition that one who undertakes supervision and care of a minor owes a duty of reasonable care to protect the child from foreseeable harm under Massachusetts common law.
*Irwin v. Town of Ware*, 392 Mass. 745,.relevant_excerpt: “Furthermore, many cases have established that liability may arise solely from the violation of an affirmative duty to act with reasonable care to prevent harm to another caused by a third person. See, e.g., Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 54 (1983)… See also… Eldredge v. Kamp Kachess Youth Serv., Inc., 90 Wash.2d 402, 408 (1978) (group child care facility's duty to control acts of delinquent children).”

*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: Entities such as community centers, schools, and youth programs that invite children onto their premises and assume custody and control of those children owe a duty to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person in similar circumstances, including (a) providing adequate supervision, (b) maintaining appropriate staff‑to‑child ratios, and (c) intervening when dangerous play or conduct arises.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with whether a social host who did not furnish or control the liquor supply owes a duty to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest. It does not involve community centers, schools, youth programs, custodial relationships with children, or any discussion of duties regarding supervision, staff‑to‑child ratios, or intervention in dangerous play. The court’s analysis is confined to social host liability in the context of alcohol and control of the liquor supply, so it does not support the proposition asserted.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff claims that these circumstances impose a common law duty in negligence on the defendant for the protection of travelers on the highways.… As discussed in the McGuiggan case supra, the decisions that have recognized social host liability under a common law theory of negligence have done so only in circumstances where the host has served or provided liquor to an intoxicated guest.… We think the factor of control should continue to be the dominant consideration in a case of this type.”

*Mueller v. N. Andover Youth Hockey Ass\.raw_text: *Mueller v. N. Andover Youth Hockey Ass’n*, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 595, 599 (1996)
*Mueller v. N. Andover Youth Hockey Ass\.proposition: Entities such as community centers, schools, and youth programs that invite children onto their premises and assume custody and control of those children owe a duty to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person in similar circumstances, including (a) providing adequate supervision, (b) maintaining appropriate staff‑to‑child ratios, and (c) intervening when dangerous play or conduct arises.
*Mueller v. N. Andover Youth Hockey Ass\.case_name: Noel v. Metropolitan Property & Liability Insurance
*Mueller v. N. Andover Youth Hockey Ass\.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is entirely about uninsured‑motorist insurance coverage and whether an insurer’s denial of a claim for lack of tort liability makes the tortfeasor an “uninsured motorist.” It does not discuss duties of community centers, schools, youth programs, or any entity’s duty to supervise or protect children. Therefore, it does not establish or support the child‑supervision duty proposition for which it is cited.
*Mueller v. N. Andover Youth Hockey Ass\.relevant_excerpt: This case turns on the proper interpretation of the Metropolitan policy. “The responsibility of construing the language of an insurance contract is a question of law for the trial judge, and then for the reviewing court.” ... As mandated by G. L. c. 175, § 113L, the Metropolitan policy provides coverage for bodily injury caused by uninsured vehicles. Part 3 of the policy, entitled “Bodily Injury Caused By An Uninsured Auto,” reads, in relevant part, as follows: “Sometimes an owner or operator of an auto legally responsible for an accident is uninsured. ...”

*Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019.raw_text: *Ferriter v. Daniel O’Connell’s Sons, Inc.*, 381 Mass. 507, 516–17 (1980)
*Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff, as parent, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the performance of its undertaking to supervise Plaintiff’s child, and to avoid subjecting Plaintiff to foreseeable economic loss and emotional distress arising from physical injury to his child.
*Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019.case_name: Ferriter v. Daniel O'Connell's Sons, Inc.
*Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a duty owed to a parent arising from the defendant’s undertaking to supervise the child and to avoid causing the parent foreseeable economic loss and emotional distress from physical injury to the child. Ferriter concerns an employer’s liability to the injured employee’s spouse and minor children for (1) loss of consortium/society and (2) negligent infliction of emotional distress when they see him after a workplace accident, plus the interaction with the workers’ compensation bar. It does not involve any undertaking to supervise a child, nor does it articulate a distinct duty owed to a parent in that supervisory context; instead it addresses family members’ derivative and independent tort claims arising from injury to an adult employee. Accordingly, it does not support the specific duty proposition stated.
*Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u2019.relevant_excerpt: “We turn to the plaintiffs' claims for negligent infliction of mental distress and impaired health…. In Dziokonski v. Babineau, supra, we held that ‘allegations concerning a parent who sustains substantial physical harm as a result of severe mental distress over some peril or harm to his minor child caused by the defendant's negligence state a claim for which relief might be granted….’ … We think that the present case is within the principles set out in Dziokonski.” (381 Mass. at 517–18).

*Dziokonski v. Babineau*, 375 Mass. 555,.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff, as parent, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the performance of its undertaking to supervise Plaintiff’s child, and to avoid subjecting Plaintiff to foreseeable economic loss and emotional distress arising from physical injury to his child.
*Dziokonski v. Babineau*, 375 Mass. 555,.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that a negligent tortfeasor may be liable to parents for their own physical injuries and emotional distress resulting from injury to their child, based on reasonable foreseeability and relational factors. But it does not involve or discuss any special duty arising from an "undertaking to supervise" the child, nor does it frame the duty in terms of avoiding parents’ foreseeable economic loss; it is a general negligence/emotional-distress foreseeability case, not a supervisory-undertaking case. Thus it does not support the specific duty proposition stated.
*Dziokonski v. Babineau*, 375 Mass. 555,.relevant_excerpt: “With these considerations in mind, we conclude that the allegations concerning a parent who sustains substantial physical harm as a result of severe mental distress over some peril or harm to his minor child caused by the defendant’s negligence state a claim for which relief might be granted, where the parent either witnesses the accident or soon comes on the scene while the child is still there.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law and frames them in terms of a defendant owing and breaching a "duty of reasonable care," which is synonymous with the degree of care a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances. Although the opinion does not use the exact phrase "reasonably prudent person," it clearly adopts the standard of reasonable care as the governing negligence standard in Massachusetts, thereby supporting the proposition in substance.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. ... We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’"

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence (duty, breach, causation, and damages) and focuses on the plaintiffs’ failure of proof on causation, but it does not state or define negligence as "the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances." The quoted passage addresses duty, causation, and statutory issues, yet nowhere articulates the classic "reasonably prudent person" standard. Thus, this case does not serve as authority for the specific proposition cited.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable where its negligent conduct is a cause of the plaintiff’s injury and the type of harm was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the conduct.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies Massachusetts proximate-cause doctrine, holding that the original negligence remains a culpable cause if the intervening act was reasonably foreseeable and that liability is governed by the “probable injurious consequences” that were to be anticipated. The court then upholds liability because it was reasonably foreseeable that leaving the forklift unsecured would result in unauthorized, dangerous operation causing injury to persons like the plaintiff. This matches the proposition that a defendant is liable where its negligence is a cause of the injury and the type of harm is a reasonably foreseeable consequence.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable where its negligent conduct is a cause of the plaintiff’s injury and the type of harm was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the conduct.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion explicitly agrees that liability turns on whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence, which matches the proposition’s focus on causation and foreseeability. While this is a concurrence rather than the majority’s full articulation of the rule, it affirms that Massachusetts law ties liability to negligent conduct causing injury of a reasonably foreseeable type.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence." Ante at 640-641.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence or conduct of third parties is alleged by Defendant, Plaintiff asserts that the negligence of Defendant was a substantial contributing factor and far exceeded any alleged negligence of others, and that Plaintiff’s minor son, given his age, cannot be found comparatively negligent under Massachusetts law.

*Gosselin v. Better Homes, Inc.*, 351 Ma.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence or conduct of third parties is alleged by Defendant, Plaintiff asserts that the negligence of Defendant was a substantial contributing factor and far exceeded any alleged negligence of others, and that Plaintiff’s minor son, given his age, cannot be found comparatively negligent under Massachusetts law.

*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence or conduct of third parties is alleged by Defendant, Plaintiff asserts that the negligence of Defendant was a substantial contributing factor and far exceeded any alleged negligence of others, and that Plaintiff’s minor son, given his age, cannot be found comparatively negligent under Massachusetts law.
*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses comparative negligence in Massachusetts and explains that under G.L. c. 231, § 85, a plaintiff’s negligence only bars recovery if it exceeds 50%, and otherwise reduces damages proportionally. It does not address any special rule for minors or state that a minor cannot be found comparatively negligent. The case involves an adult plaintiff and contains no age‑based limitation on comparative negligence, so it does not support the proposition that a minor cannot be comparatively negligent under Massachusetts law.
*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.relevant_excerpt: "Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.)."

*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.raw_text: *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002)
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees and agents under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that traditional respondeat superior applies to a corporate employer of a physician and that the employer is vicariously liable for the physician-employee’s negligent acts committed within the scope of employment, without needing to control specific treatment decisions. The opinion reverses summary judgment precisely because, once employment is established, the only remaining question is whether the negligence occurred within the scope of that employment, thereby affirming the proposition stated.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.relevant_excerpt: “Because we conclude that traditional respondeat superior liability applies to the employer of a physician, and that to establish such liability it is not necessary that the employer have the right or ability to control the specific treatment decisions of a physician-employee, we vacate the judgment and remand… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment… occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.”

*Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent tortfeasor is responsible for all damages that are the natural and probable consequence of the negligent act, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses evidentiary rulings, jury instructions, income tax issues, interest, future earning capacity, and excessiveness of damages. It assumes a standard tort damages framework (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of earning capacity, disfigurement), but it does not articulate the general Massachusetts rule that a negligent tortfeasor is liable for all natural and probable consequences of the negligence, nor does it expressly mention loss of enjoyment of life as a separate damage element. Thus, it does not serve as direct authority for the broad proposition stated.
*Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was unable to work from July 12, 1970, to March 29, 1971. Since then, she testified, she has been employed as a legal secretary, and has been able to do her work. Her doctor testified that she had a loss of function of 45% in her left hand, 25% in her right hand, and 30% in her knee joints… The assessment of damages for impairment of earning capacity rests largely on the common knowledge of the jury… There was evidence to support a finding that there would be substantial loss of earning capacity in the future. More important, there was evidence of enormous pain and suffering…”}

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent tortfeasor is responsible for all damages that are the natural and probable consequence of the negligent act, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The portion of Payton v. Abbott Labs provided does not discuss the general scope of damages recoverable in negligence (such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life), nor does it articulate a broad ‘natural and probable consequence’ damages rule. Instead, it addresses whether emotional distress without physical harm is compensable, wrongful life–type issues, prenatal injury claims, retroactivity, and market-share liability. Because the cited pages do not set out or apply the general Massachusetts damages principle described in the proposition, this case does not support that specific proposition.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: We remain convinced that the possibilities of fictitious claims and recovery of damages based on speculation should not bar the plaintiffs' action for injuries that can be demonstrated to exist by medical evidence, and for all harm to the plaintiffs that is naturally and reasonably related to those injuries. The certified question assumes that the plaintiffs can prove negligence and causation. "If the tortious conduct and the legal causation of the harm can be satisfactorily established, there may be recovery for any injury occurring at any time after conception." Restatement (Second) of Torts § 869, Comment d (1979).

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: The Court’s jurisdiction and authority are further supported by Massachusetts statutes, including but not limited to:

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts rules.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including filing fees and other recoverable costs as permitted by G.L. c. 261;
